title: On the Origin of Species
author: Charles Darwin
description: On the Origin of Species by Charles Darwin is one of the most influential scientific works ever published. First released in 1859, the book introduces the theory of evolution by natural selection, explaining how species adapt and change over time through inherited variations.  Darwin presents extensive evidence from biology, geology, and observation of nature to challenge the idea of fixed species. The work revolutionized scientific thought and reshaped humanity’s understanding of life, diversity, and the natural world. It remains a cornerstone of modern biology and scientific inquiry.

title: The Meanings of Romance: Rethinking Early Modern Fiction
author: Christine S. Lee
description: arly modern scholars often use the term ‘‘romance’’ in speaking about Renaissance literature. Loose and ill-defined as it is, ‘‘romance’’ still seems the best fit for all those curious older form of fictions we cannot quite call ‘‘novels,’’ distant as they are from the conventions of modern realism. Today we use ‘‘romance’’ quite broadly: we speak of chivalric romances such as Ariosto’s Orlando furioso (1516, 1532), pastoral romances such as Sannazaro’s Arcadia (1504), or Greek romances like the Aethiopica of Helio- dorus (third or fourth century CE), for example. ‘‘Romance’’ has become the word that indicates one of our most powerful genre categories, inspir- ing a long tradition of theory from W. P. Ker, Erich Auerbach, Northrop Frye, Patricia Parker, David Quint, and many others.1 But for sixteenth- century readers, the term as we understand it now did not exist. Much of what we today call Renaissance ‘‘romance’’ was, in its own day, a genre with- out a name—if, in fact, the authors of the new modes of fiction believed they worked within a common genre at all

title: On the Origin of Species
author: Charles Darwin
description:
On the Origin of Species by Charles Darwin is one of the most influential scientific works ever published. First released in 1859, the book introduces the theory of evolution by natural selection, explaining how species adapt and change over time through inherited variations.

Darwin presents extensive evidence from biology, geology, and observation of nature to challenge the idea of fixed species. The work revolutionized scientific thought and reshaped humanity’s understanding of life, diversity, and the natural world. It remains a cornerstone of modern biology and scientific inquiry.

title: The French Revolution
author: Thomas Carlyle
description:
The French Revolution: A History by Thomas Carlyle is a powerful and dramatic narrative of one of the most transformative events in world history. First published in 1837, the book explores the social injustice, political turmoil, and revolutionary passions that led to the fall of the French monarchy and the rise of a new social order.

Carlyle’s vivid, almost novel-like style brings historical figures and events to life, capturing the chaos, heroism, and tragedy of the Revolution. The work examines themes of power, justice, revolution, and human struggle, making it a landmark in historical writing and political thought.

title: The Federalist Papers
author: Hamilton, Madison, Jay
description:
The Federalist Papers is a foundational collection of 85 political essays written between 1787 and 1788 by Alexander Hamilton, James Madison, and John Jay. Published under the pseudonym “Publius,” these essays were written to persuade the citizens of New York to ratify the United States Constitution.

The work explains key constitutional principles such as separation of powers, checks and balances, federalism, judicial review, and representative government. Widely regarded as one of the most important texts in political philosophy and constitutional law, The Federalist Papers continues to shape legal interpretation and democratic thought around the world.

title: Wheels-Within
author: Charles V. De Vet
description: Wheels Within is a classic science fiction story that explores identity, perception, and control within a futuristic setting. The novel blends mystery and speculative ideas, keeping readers engaged with its psychological depth and unexpected twists.

title: Five Weeks in a Balloon
author: Jules Verne
description: Five Weeks in a Balloon is Jules Verne’s thrilling adventure about Dr. Samuel Ferguson, his servant Joe, and explorer Richard “Dick” Kennedy, who travel across Africa in a hydrogen balloon. The story combines scientific curiosity, danger, and exploration, showing the challenges of travel in unknown lands and Verne’s imagination for technology and adventure.

title: Badge of Infamy
author: Lester del Rey
description:
Badge of Infamy follows Dr. Daniel Feldman, a talented doctor who is punished by a corrupt medical system and forced to live outside society.
He discovers political secrets, medical corruption, and a threat that could destroy humanity.
The story shows how one honest man fights against an unfair system to save lives.

title: The Story of the Three Bears
author: Robert Southey
description: The Story of the Three Bears (1837) is the original version of the famous tale commonly known today as “Goldilocks and the Three Bears.” Written by Robert Southey, the story features three bears living in a cottage in the woods—a large Papa Bear, a medium-sized Mama Bear, and a small Baby Bear. One day, an unexpected visitor enters their home, tastes their porridge, breaks a chair, and falls asleep in one of their beds. Southey’s tale is considered the first recorded literary version of the story, blending gentle humor with a simple moral about respecting others’ property.

title: Arabian Nights (One Thousand and One Nights)
author: Anonymous
description: Arabian Nights, also known as One Thousand and One Nights, is a legendary collection of Middle Eastern and South Asian folk tales passed down through generations. The stories are framed by the captivating tale of Scheherazade, who tells a new story each night to delay her execution by King Shahryar. The collection includes iconic tales such as Aladdin, Ali Baba and the Forty Thieves, Sinbad the Sailor, The Fisherman and the Genie, and many more. Blending magic, adventure, romance, mystery, and moral lessons, it remains one of the most influential works in world literature, showcasing the richness of Arabic, Persian, and Indian storytelling traditions

title: The Green Fairy Book
author: Andrew Lang
description: The Green Fairy Book (1892) is the third volume in Andrew Lang’s celebrated Fairy Book series. It gathers a diverse collection of magical tales from countries such as Spain, Serbia, Iceland, Portugal, and Scandinavia. The stories feature enchanted animals, brave heroes, clever princesses, witches, giants, and mystical quests. Known for preserving authentic folklore, this volume includes memorable tales like "The Blue Bird," "The Half-Chick," "The Three Princesses of Whiteland," "The Little Soldier," and many others. It remains a beloved classic of international fairy tales, rich in adventure and imagination.

title: The Blue Fairy Book
author: Andrew Lang
description: The Blue Fairy Book is the first volume in Andrew Lang’s famous Fairy Book series, published in 1889. It is a richly curated collection of traditional fairy tales sourced from cultures around the world. The book includes beloved classics such as Cinderella, Sleeping Beauty, Beauty and the Beast, Little Red Riding Hood, Jack and the Beanstalk, Rumpelstiltskin, and many others. Lang’s collection preserves the original charm, magic, and moral lessons of these stories, making it one of the earliest and most influential fairy-tale anthologies in English literature.

title: Grimm’s Fairy Tales
author: Brothers Grimm
description: Grimm’s Fairy Tales is a classic collection of German folk stories compiled by Jacob and Wilhelm Grimm. First published in the 19th century, the book contains timeless tales such as Cinderella, Snow White, Hansel and Gretel, Rapunzel, Rumpelstiltskin, The Frog Prince, and many more. These stories blend magic, adventure, moral lessons, and dark folklore elements. The collection preserves traditional European storytelling and remains one of the most famous fairy-tale anthologies in the world.

title: The colour out of space
author: H. P. Lovecraft
description: The Colour Out of Space is a seminal work of cosmic horror by H. P. Lovecraft. The story follows a rural New England farmstead struck by a mysterious meteorite that emits an incomprehensible color. As the strange influence spreads, it corrupts the land, the water, the plants, animals, and eventually the family living there. The narrative explores the unknowable and alien nature of cosmic forces, emphasizing humanity’s helplessness against incomprehensible extraterrestrial phenomena. It is celebrated for its unsettling atmosphere, imaginative horror, and exploration of forces beyond human understanding

title: The festival
author: H. P. Lovecraft
description: The Festival is a chilling short story by H. P. Lovecraft that follows an unnamed narrator returning to his ancestral town of Kingsport during the Yuletide season. He discovers a secretive, centuries-old festival where the townsfolk engage in eerie rituals with unsettling, otherworldly undertones. As the night unfolds, the narrator encounters grotesque beings and uncovers terrifying family secrets, blending cosmic horror with the atmospheric dread of New England’s coastal towns. The story highlights Lovecraft’s mastery of suspense, the uncanny, and the influence of ancient, hidden forces on ordinary life.

title: The trap
author: Henry S. Whitehead and H. P. Lovecraft
description: The Trap is a supernatural horror tale co-written by Henry S. Whitehead and H. P. Lovecraft. The story revolves around a mysterious mirror owned by a schoolteacher, Mr. Bennett. When a student, Barry, disappears after touching the mirror’s surface, his friend attempts to uncover the truth. What initially seems like a harmless antique turns out to be a gateway to a strange, other-dimensional realm—one that traps those who cross its threshold. Blending eerie atmosphere, subtle cosmic horror, and psychological tension, the story explores themes of alternate realities and the terrifying unknown hidden behind everyday objects.

title: The Dunwich Horror
author: H.P. Lovecraft
description: The Dunwich Horror is one of Lovecraft’s most famous stories, set in the isolated rural town of Dunwich, where strange events surround the birth of Wilbur Whateley, an unnaturally gifted and unnervingly inhuman child. As Wilbur grows, so does a mysterious and invisible entity hidden within the Whateley farmhouse. When the creature finally breaks free, chaos and terror spread across Dunwich. Blending occult themes, cosmic dread, and forbidden knowledge, the story follows scholars from Miskatonic University as they confront an ancient, otherworldly threat tied to the dark god Yog-Sothoth.

title: The Shadow Over Innsmouth
author: H.P. Lovecraft
description: The Shadow Over Innsmouth is a classic horror novella by H.P. Lovecraft that follows a young traveler who visits the decaying seaside town of Innsmouth. The town’s eerie atmosphere, strange inhabitants, and whispers of a dark pact with sea-dwelling creatures slowly reveal a terrifying secret. As the narrator uncovers the truth behind Innsmouth’s cursed history and the mysterious Deep Ones, the story builds into one of Lovecraft’s most chilling tales of forbidden lineage, ancient gods, and creeping dread.

title: The Nicomachean Ethics
author: Aristotle
description: Nicomachean Ethics is Aristotle’s foundational work on moral philosophy, exploring what it means to live a good and fulfilling life. Aristotle argues that true happiness (eudaimonia) is achieved through the practice of virtue—finding balance between extremes in actions and emotions. Through logical reasoning and practical examples, he explains virtues like courage, justice, and temperance. This timeless text remains central to ethical theory and discussions on human character.

title: The Republic
author: Plato
description: The Republic is Plato’s most influential philosophical work, presented as a dialogue led by Socrates. It explores the nature of justice, the ideal society, the roles of citizens, and the qualities of a true philosopher-king. The book also includes the famous “Allegory of the Cave,” illustrating how education leads the mind from illusion to truth. A foundational text in Western philosophy, it continues to shape political theory, ethics, and education.

title: Emile, or On Education
author: Jean-Jacques Rousseau
description: Emile, or On Education is Rousseau’s groundbreaking work on how a child should be raised to become a free, moral, and natural human being. Through the fictional student Emile, Rousseau explains each stage of development—infancy, childhood, adolescence—and emphasizes learning through experience, curiosity, and personal freedom rather than strict instruction. This influential book shaped modern education, child psychology, and Enlightenment thought.

title: Jennie-Gerhardt
author: Theodore Dreiser
description: Jennie Gerhardt tells the heartbreaking story of a young, gentle, hardworking woman who becomes entangled in social and emotional struggles beyond her control. Set in early 20th-century America, the novel explores poverty, love, sacrifice, and society’s harsh judgment. Through Jennie’s journey, Dreiser shows how class differences and societal expectations shape individual lives.

title: Jennie Gerhardt
author: Theodore Dreiser
description: Jennie Gerhardt tells the heartbreaking story of a young, gentle, hardworking woman who becomes entangled in social and emotional struggles beyond her control. Set in early 20th-century America, the novel explores poverty, love, sacrifice, and society’s harsh judgment. Through Jennie’s journey, Dreiser shows how class differences and societal expectations shape individual lives.

title: The Age of Invention
author: Holland Thompson
description: The Age of Invention explores how mechanical innovation transformed society during the Industrial Revolution. The book highlights the development of key machines, inventions, and systems that reshaped transportation, communication, manufacturing, and daily life. It provides a clear, engaging look at the inventors, challenges, and breakthroughs that helped build the modern world.

title: Laughing Last
author: Jane Abbott
description: Laughing Last by Jane Abbott is a heartfelt story exploring family ties, personal growth, and emotional challenges. The novel follows characters navigating life’s complexities, learning lessons about resilience, loyalty, and what it means to truly “laugh last” in the face of struggles.

title: Oh, Well, You Know How Women Are AND 'Isn't That Just Like a Man
author: Irvin Shrewsbury Cobb
description: This humorous double-piece book presents witty and satirical takes on gender stereotypes. Cobb’s essay pokes fun at common sayings about women, while Rinehart’s counterpart humorously highlights clichés about men. Through their playful writing, both authors expose the exaggerated assumptions society holds about gender.

title: The Art of Money Getting
author: P. T. Barnum
description: The Art of Money Getting is P. T. Barnum’s classic guide on earning, saving, and managing money wisely. Through simple, practical rules, Barnum teaches the habits, attitudes, and decisions that lead to financial success. His advice remains surprisingly relevant even today.

title: The-Coming-of-the-Fairies
author: Arthur Conan Doyle
description: In The Coming of the Fairies, Arthur Conan Doyle explores the famous Cottingley Fairies photographs that captivated the world in the early 20th century. He presents the evidence he believed supported the existence of fairies and discusses spiritualism, photographic proof, and public reactions. The book reflects Doyle’s deep interest in the supernatural.

title: Walden
author: Henry David Thoreau
description:
Walden is Henry David Thoreau’s famous reflection on simple living in natural surroundings. Based on his two-year experiment living in a small cabin near Walden Pond, the book explores self-reliance, simplicity, personal independence, and harmony with nature.
The companion essay, On the Duty of Civil Disobedience, argues for the moral responsibility to resist unjust government actions peacefully.

title: Queen-Elizabeth
author: Jacob Abbott
description: Queen Elizabeth by Jacob Abbott offers an accessible and engaging biography of Elizabeth I, one of England’s most remarkable monarchs. Abbott traces her early struggles, political challenges, rivalry with Mary Queen of Scots, and her successful reign known as the Elizabethan era. Written in a clear narrative style, the book highlights her intelligence, diplomacy, leadership, and the cultural flourishing that marked her time on the throne.

title: Ferdinand De Soto, The Discoverer of the Mississippi
author: John S. C. Abbott
description: “Ferdinand De Soto, The Discoverer of the Mississippi” explores the adventurous life of Hernando (Ferdinand) de Soto, the Spanish conquistador who led one of the most ambitious and perilous expeditions in North America during the 16th century. The book traces his rise from humble beginnings to his role in major expeditions in Peru, Cuba, and ultimately the discovery of the Mississippi River. It highlights his leadership, courage, ambition, and the dramatic encounters between European explorers and Native American civilizations.

title: The Life and Adventures of Hernando de Soto
author: John S.C. Abbott
description: The Life and Adventures of Hernando de Soto by John S. C. Abbott recounts the dramatic and adventurous life of the Spanish explorer who led one of the most ambitious expeditions across the southeastern regions of North America. Abbott presents de Soto’s early years, his role in the conquest of Peru, his explorations through Florida, Georgia, and the Mississippi Valley, and the challenges, discoveries, and conflicts that shaped his journey. The book blends history with vivid storytelling, offering an engaging portrait of a complex figure from the Age of Exploration.

title: The Life of George Washington
author: Washington Irving
description: The Life of George Washington by Washington Irving is a richly detailed and narrative-driven biography of America’s first president. Drawing from historical records, letters, and eyewitness accounts, Irving presents Washington as a soldier, statesman, and visionary leader. The work offers an engaging portrait of his early life, military career, role in the American Revolution, presidency, and lasting legacy.

title: Life of Abraham Lincoln
author: Nicolay & Hay
description: Life of Abraham Lincoln by Nicolay and Hay is an authoritative biography written by Lincoln’s personal secretaries. Based on firsthand experience and original documents, it provides a detailed account of Lincoln’s early life, political rise, leadership during the Civil War, and his enduring legacy. It remains one of the most comprehensive and reliable biographies of the 16th U.S. president.

title: Measles
author: W. C. Rucker
description: Measles by W. C. Rucker is an informative medical guide explaining the nature, symptoms, spread, and management of measles from a historical public health perspective. It provides clear explanations intended to help readers understand the disease and its prevention.

title: How to Use Your Mind
author: Harry D. Kitson
description: This classic guide teaches the psychological principles behind effective study habits. Harry D. Kitson explains how the mind works during learning and how students can use scientific methods to improve memory, focus, motivation, and overall academic performance. The book also offers practical suggestions for teachers overseeing supervised study.

title: Herself
author: E. B. Lowry
description: Herself is a practical and insightful guide written to educate women about their bodies, health, habits, and personal well-being. It provides advice on hygiene, self-care, character, and womanly responsibilities, reflecting early 20th-century perspectives. The book aims to help women understand themselves better and lead healthier, more purposeful lives.

title: Herbal Simples Approved for Modern Uses of Cure
author: William Thomas Fernie
description: Herbal Simples Approved for Modern Uses of Cure is a practical guide to herbal medicine written by William Thomas Fernie. The book explores the healing properties of common herbs and plants, explaining their traditional uses, medicinal benefits, and historical significance. Fernie blends folklore, herbal science, and practical advice to offer a comprehensive resource for natural cures.

title: Observations of an Orderly
author: Ward Muir
description: Observations of an Orderly is Ward Muir’s first-hand account of his experiences working as an orderly in a British war hospital during World War I. Written with honesty, warmth, and humor, the book reveals the daily routines, emotional struggles, and human stories behind the scenes of wartime medical care. Muir describes the wounded soldiers, the nursing staff, the discipline of hospital life, and the emotional weight of treating men broken by war.

title: Power of Mental Imagery
author: Warren Hilton
description: This book explores how different types of mental imagery (visual, auditory, tactile, etc.) affect thinking, memory, creativity, and action. Hilton examines how people can harness their imagination in a structured way to influence themselves and others, improve business performance, and achieve personal goals. The book also provides practical tests and exercises to improve one’s mental imagery capacity.

title: Woher die Kindlein kommen
author: Paula Dehmel
description: Woher die Kindlein kommen is a gentle, illustrated children’s book that explains the origins of babies in a poetic and imaginative way. Written by Paula Dehmel, it uses symbolic language and charming storytelling to address a sensitive topic in a way suitable for children. The book reflects early 20th-century educational styles and family-centered storytelling.

title: Surgical Experiences in South Africa, 1899–1900
author: George Henry Makins
description: This work is a detailed medical account of surgical cases and observations made during the South African (Boer) War of 1899–1900. George Henry Makins, a British military surgeon, documents the nature of gunshot wounds, surgical procedures, recovery outcomes, and the challenges of treating soldiers under battlefield conditions.

title: How to Use Your Mind
author: Harry D. Kitson, Ph.D.
description: This book is a practical manual that teaches students how to study more effectively by understanding the psychology behind learning. It covers concentration, memory, habit formation, note-taking, and time management — all rooted in scientific principles of mental efficiency.

title: Dietetics for Nurses
author: Fairfax T. Proudfit
description: Dietetics for Nurses is a practical guide designed to help nursing students and professionals understand the principles of human nutrition and their application in patient care. It explains how diet affects recovery, health maintenance, and disease management, offering guidance on meal planning, food preparation, and therapeutic diets.

title: The Maternal Management of Children in Health and Disease.
author: Thomas Bull, M.D.
description: This classic 19th-century guide offers practical advice for mothers on how to care for children from birth through early childhood. It covers topics such as nutrition, hygiene, sleep, illness prevention, and moral upbringing. Written in clear and instructive language, the book reflects early medical and domestic practices aimed at ensuring both the physical and emotional well-being of children.

title: The Silver Box
author: John Galsworthy
description: The Silver Box is a powerful social drama by John Galsworthy that exposes the stark inequalities between the rich and the poor in early 20th-century England. The play begins with a simple theft—a silver cigarette box—but quickly develops into a profound critique of class privilege and justice. Through the contrasting treatment of two men accused of similar crimes, Galsworthy highlights the hypocrisy of a system that favors wealth over truth and fairness.

title: Arms and the Man
author: George Bernard Shaw
description: Arms and the Man is a witty romantic comedy by George Bernard Shaw that satirizes the glorification of war and romantic ideals. Set during the Serbo-Bulgarian War, the play follows Raina Petkoff, a young Bulgarian woman, whose notions of heroism are challenged when she meets Captain Bluntschli, a pragmatic Swiss soldier who values common sense over bravery. Through sharp humor and clever dialogue, Shaw exposes the absurdities of war, love, and social pretensions, making this one of his most enduring and thought-provoking comedies.
